Posts.Title: Things the past year has taught me... SelenaWolf tenaj

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2012 04:13PM sbaaronson wrote: Hi, I was able to continue working out through chemo and radiation, 4 rds TC but it slowed me down. You are winded because your red count is down. Less oxygen floating around. What I found is that you round corners; meaning you will start feeling better (and be conscious of it) periodically - it builds on itself. Remember you lose muscle mass during chemo and there are hormonal changes to deal with too! I am 15 months post chemo now and in terms of workouts, I am doing what I did before BC. However, my body is not the same. I am in menopause now and rebuilding the muscle mass takes more time than in did in the past. My RO just told me last week that it hasn't been long enough yet. She says give it another 6 months. That puts me close to the 2 year mark... You'll run another race!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 11:44AM sbaaronson wrote: I wouldn't tell them about your medical history. Everyone does have doctors appt's. You can always talk to them about it at a later date. My feeling is this, divulging this kind of information crosses the line from a professional relationship to a personal one. Congrats on your new position!

Posts.Title: Young and Over Yet (bad PET> Tiger_Blood vickib

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 02:00AM sbaaronson wrote: Hi Soleil, I am not stage IV but I do have a morning protein/smoothie routine that I like. The protein powder is called: Protein and Greens by Paradise. 2 scoops gives you 22 g of protein. I use 3 and make it 33gs. In addition to the powder I use a cup of mixed berries (frozen), 2 TBS of FiProFlax by Health from the Sun (another 3 g of protein) and a big handful of whichever greens I have in the house - kale, spinach, chard, etc. Sometimes I throw in a banana or a whole orange. You could also consider Chia Seeds rather than the FiProFlax to mix it up a bit. I use the above as my post-gym breakfast and I really notice a difference! Best wishes for 2013- Stacey

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 07:23PM sbaaronson wrote: I had horrible SE's but I went to my Integrated Medicine Oncologist and told her I needed herbs and supplements to help with these. They have allowed me to stay on the Tamoxifen. Before I threw in the towel on this drug, I would exhaust every alternative.
Posts.Title: Anyone out there decline taking Tamoxifen? tmetz1616 shelly56

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 05:16PM sbaaronson wrote: I am not a stage 3 either. My apologies for barging in on the stage 3 thread. But, I am having one of those days where the worry is with me. Perhaps because I have a cold or the flu and not feeling well now vs pre-bc will forever be associated with "not being well/chemo." The fear comes and goes... I find I am either slogging through it, like today, or I am going full boar in my everyday life, no time to contemplate the fear. I had a colleague say to me, during my treatment, that tomorrow is promised to no one. I think, pre-bc, I assumed I would live into my 80's and see my children become adults. I think, the brick wall we all hit with this thing is the realization that there was never a guarantee. What we lost was the ability to go about life under this illusion. My MO nurse once said to me, as I was breaking down while on the table getting ready for my post-treatment scan. Don't let the fear in, Not Here, Not Now, Not Today.  Words to live by...
Posts.Title: Fear of Metasteses - How to cope Elizabeth1959 sugarplum

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2013 09:09PM sbaaronson wrote: Hi, I have always been a runner-low blood pressure, great cardio capacity. It took me a long time to stop feeling short of breath and tired after chemo. And, just to let you know, I am 2 1/2 years post chemo and my red count is still not in the normal range. I assume this low count is my new normal. The comeback is a long process... One day at a time... Stacey

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 05:59PM sbaaronson wrote: Hi Quiltrunner, I felt like I was hobbled, my feet hurt so bad! When I got out of bed in the morning or the middle of the night, it was the worst... In fact, 2 1/2 years later, I still have that same pain come back on me from time to time. I complained to my MO during chemo. Her response, "your feet?!" Feel better soon- Stacey

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2013 06:24PM sbaaronson wrote: Hi, I have just a smidge of LE, it comes and goes... I fly quite a bit for business, just did Auckland - Los Angeles yesterday. This is my routine- 2 capsules of Venastat and wrapping my arm with an old fashion ace bandage. I also wear compression socks, get them from the drug store. My theory is these help keep the system moving. Venastat contains an all-natural standardized horse chestnut seed extract. I haven't had any problems!!! Knock on wood!!! Best, Stacey
